text: Applications
ACE 3-1

a. Natasha charges $12 per hour for babysitting in her neighborhood. What equation relates her pay for a job to the number of hours she works?

b. A gasoline service station offers 20 cents off the regular price per gallon every Tuesday. What equation relates the discounted price to the regular price on that day?

a. p = 12h, where p is Natasha’s pay and h is the number of hours she works.

b. d = r − 0.20, where d is the discounted price per gallon and r is the regular price per gallon.
ACE 3-2

A middle school wants to have its students see a movie at a local theater. The total cost of the theater is $1,500 to cover the cost for each student. What equation shows how the cost per student depends on the number of students who attend?
C = 1,500 ÷ n, where C is the cost in dollars per student and n is the number of students.
ACE 3-3

Celia writes the equation d = 8t to represent the distance in miles d that riders could travel in t hours at a speed of 8 miles per hour. Make a table that shows the distance traveled every half hour, up to 5 hours, if riders travel at this constant speed.
ACE 3-4

A girls’ basketball team is playing in the Texas state championship game. They are going 560 miles from El Paso to San Antonio. Their bus travels at an average speed of 60 miles per hour.

a. Suppose the bus travels at an almost steady speed throughout the trip. Make a table and a graph of time and distance data for the bus.

b. Estimate the distance the bus travels in 2 hours, 2¾ hours, 3½ hours, and 7.25 hours.

c. Describe in words and with an equation a rule you could use to calculate the distance traveled for any given time on this trip.

d. The bus route passes through Sierra Blanca, which is 90 miles from El Paso. About how long does it take the bus to get to Sierra Blanca?

e. The bus route also passes through Balmorhea, which is ⅓ of the way from El Paso to San Antonio. About how long does it take the bus to get to Balmorhea?

f. How long does it take the bus to complete its 560-mile trip to San Antonio?

g. Explain in words and with an equation how time t for the 560-mile trip depends on average speed s.

h. Use the rule from ACE 4g to calculate trip time if the average bus speed is 50 miles per hour, 45 miles per hour, and 70 miles per hour.

b. The bus travels 120 miles in 2 hours, 165 miles in 2¾ hours, 210 miles in 3½ hours, and 435 miles in 7.25 hours.

c. The distance in miles is 60 miles per hour times the number of hours. An equation is d = 60t, where d is the distance in miles and t is the time in hours.

d. The bus takes 1.5 hours to reach Sierra Blanca because 90 ÷ 60 = 1.5. Students may say that 90 miles is the halfway point between 60 miles (1 hour) and 120 miles (2 hours).

e. Balmorhea is 560 ÷ 3 miles from El Paso. That will take 3 1/9 hours, or 3 hours and 6 ⅔ minutes. 560 divided by 3 is about 187 miles. The question asks students to estimate, so accept the argument that if they are traveling 60 miles per hour, it will take just over 3 hours.

f. The whole trip will take 9 ⅓ hours, or 9 hours and 20 minutes.

g. The amount of time decreases as the average speed increases for the 560-mile trip. An equation is t = 560 ÷ s.

h. Trip time will be 11.2 hours (11 hours and 12 minutes) at 50 miles per hour; 12.44 hours (12 hours and about 26 minutes) at 45 miles per hour, and 8 hours at 70 miles per hour.
ACE 3-5

The table shows the relationship between the number of riders on a bike tour and the daily cost of providing box lunches.

a. Explain in words and with an equation how lunch cost L depends on the number of riders n.

b. Use your equation to find the lunch cost for 25 riders.

c. How many riders could eat lunch for $89.25? Explain how you found your answer.

a. As the number of people increases by 1, there is an increase of $4.25 in the lunch cost. An equation for the relationship is L = 4.25n.

b. 25 × $4.25 = $106.25

c. You can get 21 lunches for $89.25. You can expand the table and look for the value that corresponds to the lunch cost, $89.25. You can make a graph of the relationship and find the x-value for y = 89.25. You can also use the equation L = 4.25n and divide $89.25 by $4.25 per lunch to get the number of lunches.
ACE 3-6

The equation d = 70t represents the distance in miles covered after traveling 70 miles per hour for t hours.

a. Make a table that shows the distance traveled every half hour from 0 hours to 4 hours.

b. Sketch a coordinate graph that shows the distance traveled between 0 and 4 hours.

c. What is d when t = 2.5 hours? Explain how you found your answer.

d. What is t when d = 210 miles? Explain how you found your answer.

e. You probably made your graph by plotting points. In this situation, would it make sense to connect these points?

c. 175 miles

Table: 2.5 hours corresponds to 175 miles of distance.

Graph: If you locate 2.5 hours on the x-axis, the corresponding y-value is 175 miles.

Equation: If you substitute 2.5 hours for t in the equation, you get 175 miles for d.

d. 3 hours

Table: 210 miles corresponds to 3 hours.

Graph: If you locate 210 miles on the y-axis, the corresponding x-value is 3 hours.

Equation: If you substitute 210 miles for 3 in the equation, you get 3 hours for h.

e. In this case, it makes sense to connect the points because the car is presumed to be moving continuously and covering distance steadily between half-hour checkpoints.
ACE 3-7

Use the equation to complete the table.

y = 100 - k
ACE 3-8

Use the equation to complete the table.

d = 3.5t
ACE 3-9

For each context in ACE 9a–c, express each rule with an equation.

Use single letters to stand for the variables. Identify what each letter represents.

a. The area of a rectangle is its length multiplied by its width.

b. The number of hot dogs needed for a picnic is 2 for each student.

c. The amount of material needed to make curtains is 4 square yards per window.

a. A = lw, where A is the area, l is the length, and w is the width

b. h = 2s, where h is the number of hot dogs and s is the number of students

c. m = 4w, where m is the amount of material in yards and w is the number of windows
Connections
ACE 3-10

Multiple Choice

Which equation describes the relationship in the table?

A. C = 10n

B. C = 10 + n

C. C = 10

Answer:

A. C = 10n
ACE 3-11

The perimeter P of a square is related to the side length s by the formula P = 4s.

a. Make a table showing how the perimeter of a square increases as the side length increases for 1 to 6 in 1-unit steps. Describe the pattern of change.

b. The area A of a square is related to the side length by the formula A = s2. Add a row to the table in ACE 11a to show how the area of the square increases as the side length increases. Describe the pattern of change.

a. The perimeter increases by 4 as the length of the side increases by 1.

b. The area increases as side length increases at a constant rate. In fact, the successive differences are the odd numbers 3, 5, 7, 9, 11, and so on. Algebraically, this is because (x + 1)2 − x2 = 2x + 1 for all x. Note: We do not expect students to use this reasoning yet.
ACE 3-12

Find the indicated value.

a. The tenth odd number (1 is the first odd number, 3 is the second odd number, and so on).

b. The area of a rectangle with a length of 10 centimeters and a width of 15 centimeters.

a. 19

b. 10 x 15 = 150
ACE 3-13

What number am I?

Clue 1. When you divide me by 5, the remainder is 1.

Clue 2. I have two digits. One digit is odd, and one digit is even.

Clue 3. The sum of my digits is 9.
ACE 3-14

2 × 6 × 5 = 60. How does knowing this fact help find the product of each of these?

a. 6 × 6 × 5

b. 2 × 6 × 10

c. 2 × 3 × 5

a. Answers will vary. Students may notice that the only factor that changed was the 2, which is now a 6; since 2 × 3 = 6, the new product will be 3 times as large, or 60 × 3 = 180.

b. Answers will vary. Students may notice that the factor of 5 is now a 10, so the product will be doubled, or twice as large; 60 × 2 = 120.

c. Answers will vary. Students may notice that the factor of 6 is now a 3, which is ½ the size, so the product will be ½ of the original product: 60 ÷ 2 = 30.
ACE 3-15
Describe the relationship between the variables, x and y, in words and with an equation.

a. y is 4 times x; y = 4x

b. t is 50 minus s; t = 50 − s
ACE 3-16
Copy and complete the table of values for the given equation.
ACE 3-17
Copy and complete the table of values for the given equation.
Extensions
ACE 3-18
For ACE 18a–c, describe in words the relationship between x and y.

a. y is equal to x.

b. y is 1 more than x.

c. The sum of x and y is 5. As x increases by 1, y decreases by 1.
ACE 3-19

You can calculate the average speed of a car trip if you know the distance and time traveled.

a. Copy and complete the table.

b. Write a formula for calculating the average speed s for any given distance d and time t.
b. s= d/t ; You can calculate average speed by dividing the distance d by the number of hours t.
ACE 3-20

Solve by guessing and checking:

The equation p = 50 + 10n gives the admission price p to Wild World for a group of n people. A club’s budget has $500 set aside for a visit to the park. How many club members can go?

45 club members

500 = 50 + 10n

500 − 50 = $450 after the $50.00 group fee is paid.

$450 divided among $10 for each is $45 per member.
ACE 3-21

Solve by guessing and checking:

The equation b = 100 − 6r gives the number of bonus points b left on a Wild World bonus card after r rides.

a. Rosi has 34 points left. How many rides has she been on?

b. Chima has 16 points left. How many rides has he been on?

a. 11 rides

34 = 100 − 6r

100 points to begin with − 34 left = 66 used

66 divided by 6 per ride = 11 rides

b. 14 rides

100 − 16 = 84 points used

84 points divided by 6 per ride is equal to 14 rides
ACE 3-22

Solve by guessing and checking:

The equation d = 2.5t describes the distance in meters d covered by a canoe-racing team in t seconds. How long does it take the team to go 125 meters? 400 meters?

50 seconds; 125 meters divided by 2.5 meters per second is equal to 50 seconds

160 seconds; 400 meters divided by 2.5 meters per second is equal to 160 seconds
ACE 3-23

Solve by guessing and checking:

The equation d = 400 − 2.5t describes the distance in meters d of a canoe-racing team from the finish line t seconds after a race starts. When is the team 175 meters from the finish line? 100 meters from the finish line?

90 seconds; 400 − 175 = 225 meters traveled so far, 225 meters divided by 2.5 meters per second is 90 seconds

120 seconds; 400 − 100 = 300 meters traveled so far, 300 meters divided by 2.5 meters per second is 120 seconds
ACE 3-24
Armen builds models from rods. When he builds bridges, he makes the sides using patterns of triangles like the ones below. The total number of rods depends on the number of rods along the bottom.

a. Copy and complete the table showing the relationship between the number of rods along the bottom and the total number of rods.

b. Write an equation relating the total number of rods t to the number of rods along the bottom b. Explain how the formula you write relates to the way Armen puts the rods together.

c. For the design below, make a table and write an equation relating the total number of rods t to the number of rods along the bottom b.

b. Possible rule: t = 4b − 1, t = 3b +b − 1, or t = 3 + 4(b − 1).

Possible explanations: The first rule comes from studying the numeric pattern. The second involves building triangles on each bottom rod and then adding one less than the number of bottom rods to connect those triangles at the top. The third involves starting the first piece with a triangle and then adding four new rods to get each additional length.

Note: With patterns like this, it is generally easier to think recursively: “What gets added (or subtracted or multiplied or divided) to produce the next step?” This does not lead naturally to a rule for any stage (without building up to it). Students will get lots of practice in both kinds of thinking in future units.

c. Possible equations: t = 3b + 1, t = 2b + b + 1, t = 4 + 3(b − 1)
ACE 3-25

The Ocean Bike Tours partners decided to include a visit to Wild World Amusement Park as part of the tour. These are the cost and income factors.

a. Combining all these factors, what equation relates expected tour profit P to the number of customers n who take the trip?

b. For what number of customers will a tour group produce profit greater than $500?

a. Students can express the given information with a variety of equivalent profit equations. At this point, students might write either the long form P = 350n − 30n − 125n − 700 − 50 − 10n − 25n or the condensed form P = 160n − 750. They might also make some common errors and write P = 350n − 30n − 125n − 700 − 50 + 10n − 25n.

b. Using either rule in part (a) and by inspecting a table or graph or by guess-and-check reasoning, the tour profit will be greater than $500 when there are at least 8 customers. $160(8) − $750 = $530, but $160(7) − $750 = $370.
ACE 3-26

Theo and Liz think about running the new Chicago Great Lakes Tour with trips for large groups. To plan, Theo looks for large group specials on websites. He finds the admission price for an adventure park.

a. Find the price of admission at the adventure park for a group of 20 people, a group of 35 people, and a group of 42 people.

b. Describe in words how you can calculate the admission price for a group with any number of people.

c. Use this information to write an equation relating admission price p to group size n.

d. Use the equation to calculate the price of admission for 30 people.

e. Use the equation to calculate the number of people in the group if the price of admission is $450.

a. $250; $400; $470

  • For a group of 20 people, the price of admission will be $50 + $10 × 20.
  • For a group of 35 people, the price of admission will be $50 + $10 × 35.
  • For a group of 42 people, the price of admission will be $50 + $10 × 42.

b. Multiply the number of people in the group by $10 and add $50.

c. price = $50 + $10 per person

p = 50 + 10n

d. p = 50 + 10 × 30 = 50 + 300 = 350. The price is $350.

e. 450 = 50 + 10 × n. The number of people is 40.
ACE 3-27

Liz wonders whether they should rent a cart to carry their backpacks. Below are an equation, table, and graph that represent the cost of renting carts.

a. What are the variables?

b. Describe the relationship between the cost and time.

c. How is the relationship represented in a table? Graph? Equation?

d. Why is there a cost for 0 hours?

e. What do these points tell us about the cart rental: (4, 40), (0, 20), (7, 55)?

f. How are these points related to the table and equation?

a. The number of hours is the independent variable, and the rental cost is the dependent variable.

b. The rental cost is increasing over time. You can see the rental cost is getting larger in the table as the number of hours increases. You can also see the data points in the graph are going up.

c. The cost per hour shows up in the table and graph as a steady rate of increase of 5 dollars for every 1 hour. It shows up in the equation as the coefficient 5.

d. When you rent a cart, you might pay the initial rental fee, and the cost goes up from there depending on the number of hours you want to rent. It might be also for those who rent a cart less than 1 hour, such as 30 minutes, 40 minutes, and so on.

e. For (4, 40), you need to pay $40 to rent a cart for 4 hours.

For (0, 20), the rental cost begins from $20.

For (7, 55), you need to pay $55 to rent a cart for 7 hours.

f. For each point (#1, #2), you can relate these numbers in the table: #1 is in the “numbers of hours” row, and #2 is in the “rental cost” row. In the equation, #2 = 20 + 5 × #1.
